ast.name: first steps with turtle
ast.comment: Start from here to build a turtle script! #docs #turtle #tutorials

body.text: Imagine that you have just received a new toy, **turtle**.
**turtle** is a virtual little turtle that moves, turns and draws with a colored pen. turtle knows only basic commands but we'll teach it a few more tricks.
* open a browser and go to [http://touchdevelop.com/](http://touchdevelop.com/)
* pick your game name and tap **create**

Let's try to draw a square with turtle. Turtle does not know about squares but it knows how to turn and move forward. So, to draw a square, we need to create a sequence of **forward moves** and **left turns**.
The **turtle drawings** template already had a little bit of code to setup the turtle world, change the pen color randomly and move the turtle forward 200.
* run the game by tapping the `[code->]` play button and see what happens
Yay! The turtle is moving up then turning left.
* press the `[←]` button on the upper left to go back to the editor.
Turtle is ready to move forward. Let's add a line of code to tell Turtle to move 200 steps **forward**.
* tap on the last line of code to select it
* tap on the bottom `[+]` button below the code to add a new line
* tap on the `[libs->turtle]` in the lower right keyboard.
This is how the code looks like in your editor.
* tap on `[forward]`. If this button is not visible, cycle through more options using the blue `[>>]` button.
This is how the code looks like in your editor.
* use the number pad in the lower right to change `0` to `200`
* run your game and see what happens
The next step is to turn again to the left.
* tap on the last line of code to select it
* tap on the `[libs->turtle]` in the lower right keyboard.
* tap on `[left turn]`. If this button is not visible, cycle through more options using the blue `[>>]` button.
* use the number pad in the lower right to change `0` to `90`
* run your game and see what happens
* add the code to move forward `200` steps
* run your game and see what happens
* add the code to turn left '`90` degrees and move forward `200` steps another time
* and one more left turn so that turtle finishes exactly where it started
* run your game and see what happens
Yay! The turtle is drawing a square!
* add a new line **above** each `libs->turtle->forward` line and change the color of the pen. Run your game and see what happens.
* add a new line at the beginning at change the thickness of the pen to  `6`. run your game to see what happens
* try changing the pen size to `20` and run your game
* change the number of steps in `libs->turtle->forward` to 150 and run your game

Telling turtle to draw a square was a lot of fun... but also a lot of typing! Imagine how much code it would take to tell it to write a hexagon or an octagon! Maybe there is something better we can do.

Did you notice that we told turtle to move `forward` and `left turn` 4 times in a row? What if instead of typing it 4 times, we could simply run the same code 4 times... This is exactly what we are going to do with a [](/for) loop.

All the code nested under the `for` will run on each loop. The idea of the `for` is that variable `index` starts at `0` and gets incremented on each loop until `index` becomes greater or equal to `4`. So `index` will take the value `0`, `1`, `2`, `3` and then the `for` will end.
* **delete all the code** by selecting each line and tapping `[cut]`
* add this line of code to make turtle faster
* tap on `[for]` in the blue button strip
* tap on `[do nothing]` **under the for**. This is where the code that needs to be repeated goes.
* add the 2 lines of code highlighted below to move forward and turn left
The vertical bars on the left show where the `for` loop ends.
* run your game and see what happens
Wow, same result with much less typing!
* change the `4` in the `for` loop into a `3`
* change the `90` degrees in the left turn into `120` degrees
* run your game and see what happens
* Modify the `for` loop to draw a hexagon.
* could you draw a circle with the turtle?
It's time to try a new trick with Logo. This time, we'll learn how to draw spirals.
Drawing a spiral is very similar to drawing a square; the only difference is that we tell Logo to move forward a little more on each iteration and we let it turn much more times.

So how do we change the number of steps in `turtle->forward` on each loop? One possible way is to use the index of the `for` loop. Instead of passing `200` to forward, we multiple`5` times the index `i` and add it to `50`:
* change the count `3` to `20` in the `for` loop
* run your game and see what happens
* change the color on before each `forward` call by using `libs->turtle->set pen color(colors->random)`. Run your game and see what happens.
* change the pen size so that it gets bigger after every move
* instead of turning `120` degrees, try turning less or more and see the effect on the spiral. Try ``60``, ``90``, ``5`` degrees... run your game and see what happens.
Here is another fun experiment to do with the turtle: draw a triangle, then turn a little, then draw another large triangle...
* **delete all the code** and replace it with
* run your game and see what happens
* change the pen color after drawing each triangle
* change the pen size after drawing each triangle
Now that you know how to give commands to the turtle, try to recreate the following drawings. Have fun!

LiASpme4XaeR2nChjb4xnnbG.text: Imagine that you have just received a cool new toy, **turtle**.

Q1GZN5KN4Gz2nyO6VFd43DPT.text: * open the TouchDevelop app for Windows Phone 8, or open a browser and go to [http://touchdevelop.com/](http://touchdevelop.com/)

xj9utVKy770qdSpB7jp9ATCW.text: * Try changing the angle to ``150`` or ``60``.

CwAIsoYtrigzJESVRPDSnFiq.text: When you are done with these challenges, try [drawing some fractals](/turtlefractalstutorial) using the turtle...

DlwGF2u7mpNbwxIEcBLTTZ87.text: * login with your Microsoft or Facebook or Google account

xg1UN8LMVO5zbHs2uYcOI2JT.text: Watch a quick tutorial on how to write your name with turtle

w4IOv7tJ60YEMmM8bR0Ht2v4.text: Skip the publishing if you do not have an internet connection.

xNIIbCkQs3w9cC34Lnka2eaS.text: Don't forget to [publish](/publishing) your script so that others can try it out!

qnCtNPwSiBer2Pr45oaMaZE8.text: watch a quick tutorial video on how to make a spiral using a loop and turtle
